title: 113_hr2352
content:
The Act is titled the "Eleanor Smith Inclusive Home Design Act of 2013" and includes definitions. The "Eleanor Smith Inclusive Home Design Act of 2013" defines a "covered dwelling unit" as a residence designed for occupancy that received Federal financial assistance for construction and is available for first occupancy after certain criteria are met. The "Eleanor Smith Inclusive Home Design Act of 2013" states that a "covered dwelling unit" is a residence that received Federal financial assistance for construction and is available for occupancy after a one-year period from the enactment of the Act. Federal financial assistance includes grants, subsidies, services, and property provided by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development or the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. The "Eleanor Smith Inclusive Home Design Act of 2013" defines a "covered dwelling unit" as a residence that received Federal financial assistance for construction and is available for occupancy after one year. This assistance includes grants, subsidies, services, and property provided by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development or the Secretary of Veterans Affairs. Additionally, the Act covers transfers or leases of property below fair market value, tax credits, mortgage guarantees, and community development funds guaranteed under section 108. The term "person or entity" includes various types of individuals and organizations, such as corporations, partnerships, associations, labor organizations, and trustees, among others. SEC. 3. VISITABILITY REQUIREMENT. It is illegal for certain individuals related to a dwelling unit to not have at least one level that meets specific accessibility standards. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. Each applicant for Federal financial assistance must assure compliance with the Act. Approval of architectural and construction plans for covered dwelling units requires submission to the appropriate State or local agency for compliance with building codes. The Act requires compliance with building codes for approval of architectural and construction plans for covered dwelling units. Enforcement actions include reviewing and approving plans based on compliance, and withholding final approval until compliance is determined. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must ensure that State or local agencies are enforcing building code compliance for covered dwelling units to receive Federal financial assistance. Private individuals can take civil action against responsible parties for violations within two years of the unlawful conduct. The Attorney General enforces violations of the Act, holding State or local agencies liable for approved plans that violate the Act and construction performed accordingly. Responsible parties are liable for construction that violates the Act despite approved plans complying with the Act. The Attorney General can take legal action in federal court against individuals or groups believed to have violated the Act. In such cases, the court may award damages and issue injunctions to prevent further violations. In civil actions under the Act, the court may order affirmative action to prevent violations. Violations involving non-conforming dwelling units are considered ongoing until corrected. The prevailing party may be awarded attorney's fees. Relief granted under this section does not affect pre-existing contracts or agreements. SEC. 5. EFFECT ON STATE LAWS.

This Act does not invalidate or limit any state law that provides the same rights as this Act. Any state law that conflicts with this Act is invalid.

SEC. 6. DISCLAIMER OF PREEMPTIVE EFFECT ON OTHER ACTS.

This Act does not limit any rights under the Constitution or other Acts of Congress.

SEC. 7. SEVERABILITY OF PROVISIONS. If any provision of this Act is deemed invalid, the rest of the Act and its application to others will not be affected.
